p.s: Shakespeare begins his sonnet by listing powerful natural forces such as the sea or stones.
He uses the anaphora nor (v. 1) to express that all those things are not strong enough to hold against mortality (v. 2).
The contrast that mortality kills their power is striking because how has death the force to take away theirs.
Death and mortality are part of nature too such as the things they destroy in the sonnet so Shakespeare transfers this to love.
It is natural that the power of love is taken away and cannot exist endlessly.
But it is also possible to compare this contrast to life in general.
The theme of transitoriness shows that nothing can resist time because it'sits power is taken away from mortality as the right time comes.
It continues with a rhetorical question asking: How with this rage shall beauty hold a plea, [w]hose action is no stronger that a flower? (v. 3f.).
It is asked how beauty can resist because everything is transitory which is also expressed by the symbol of the flower (v. 4).
A flower wilts after a time and does not live in eternity.
Again there are different themes this can be transferred to.
Love is an important factor but also youth is a possibility to interpret those lines.
A human can be compared to the flower wilting slowly.
The personification summer's honey breath (v. 5) is used to refer to sweet and good times in life such as the youth or the time in a love relationship.
Besides those positive experiences there are wrackful [sieges] of batt'ring days (v. 6) showing that nothing can live through all times.
Even the hardest rocks do not remain impregnable (v. 7) such as gates of steel (v. 8).
Asking if even time decays (v. 8) shows the doubt about the eternity of everything.
The exclamation O fearful meditation! (v. 9), expresses the surprise realization of the narrator.
They are disappointed and search for a solution to avoid the ending of every thing.
It is asked if time's best jewel from time's chest lie hid? (v. 10) or if there is a possibility to break out of time to resist it.
The narrator wants to use a strong hand to hold his swift foot back (v. 11).
The swift foot which is discribeddescribed is used as a symbol for the fast continuing time.
In the end the narrator hopes for a miracle (v. 13) but it sure that the black ink (v. 14) will stay.
The letter written with this Ing.
is a consolation because the narrator thinks that it will not feed and that there is hope that something can resist time.
There is also a personification of the force of love which can be transferred to the addressee.
Referring again to the theme of love the narrator hopes that the love expressed through the words written will not become a victim of time.
The main message of the sonnet is that nothing is able to resist time.
Not a human life and it'sits youth nor love even though the narrator of hope so.
Compared to Shakespeare's catalogue of sonnets this one is quite special.
It includes typical themes of Shakespeare's sonnets for example love and nature but also stands in contrast to them.
The main theme is the transitoriness of everything but other Shakespearean sonnets mainly are about never ending love or youth.
Comparing Sonnet 65 to a play like Romeo and Juliet too you can see that the characters are not even pulled apart in death.
